awd_titl_txt: A Virtual Organization to Enhance the Use of CISE Community Research Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the creation of a virtual organization to promote sharing and use of community research infrastructures by Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) researchers.  The project includes development and operation of a central resource with information about CISE community infrastructures, including how researchers can use the resources and participate in community events.   The project also includes organizing annual community meetings for the researchers who are developing and hosting CISE community research infrastructures.  Computing and information science is a rapidly evolving field that often requires current, state-of-the-art research infrastructure to conduct quality, significant research.    This project fulfills a long-standing need to provide accurate and timely information about the community infrastructures collectively as well as individually and help researchers determine effective ways to conduct their research, particularly in an environment where there are limited local research resources available to them. Providing well-designed and managed community research infrastructure is one method of enabling a broader, diverse CISE research community to collaborate and participate in compelling research that will move CISE research frontiers forward.

This project will develop a platform where researchers can learn about new resources and participate in community events to exchange information on research ideas and use of the infrastructures.  It builds a unique "community of practice" focused on CISE research infrastructure.  This will require research and experimentation to determine the most pressing community needs, to design modes of communications to streamline information flows, and to create a platform that enables the formation and growth of new collaborations across the community. This should provide new avenues for CISE research and research collaborations, particularly those that focus on emerging technologies and promote opportunities for unique, new research directions

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CCRI-VO established a model platform for collecting and organizing information on computing research infrastructures, encompassing testbed networks, prototype platforms, training datasets, and software repositories. By developing a taxonomy tailored to the classification of these infrastructures, the CCRI-VO can support future efforts to catalog and organize infrastructure metadata, assisting future efforts to develop systems for finding and navigating diverse resources to support future computing research.

By promoting the development of detailed descriptions of infrastructures and the research topics to which they can be applied, the CCRI-VO also enables the computing research community to understand the broad range of infrastructures that are required to maintain a competitive computing ecosystem. The linking of infrastructures to topics and applications demonstrates the relationships between infrastructures. It also highlights how different segments of the computing research community share common infrastructures and resources, demonstrating the need for greater coordination among research subcommunities. This could also identify opportunities for greater efficiency in the development of future infrastructures by finding areas where resources could be shared rather than duplicated, and by describing gaps in the current array of infrastructures that should be targeted for future support. Since the classification scheme is based on the ACM research taxonomy, matching infrastructure categories to the focus areas of current graduate students and early-career researchers could also map current and future infrastructure demand to the current inventory of infrastructures, guiding further funding strategies.

The CCRI-VO project also demonstrated the interdisciplinary nature of computing research infrastructures. Some infrastructures have broad application and support the types of research that can benefit multiple disciplines, e.g., the use of infrastructures to support advances in machine learning to produce algorithms and computing techniques with broad application across the sciences. Other infrastructures are enabled by interdisciplinary collaboration, such as the effort to develop better infrastructures for sound processing (which benefits from advances in neurosciences and the study of human auditory systems) or text analytics (closely related to research on linguistics and history). While the CCRI-VO primarily supported the needs of CISE grantees, the nature of computing as a general purpose technology means that support for computing infrastructures provides a foundation for enabling many disciplines to benefit from the tools and techniques created on these systems.

The CCRI-VO virtual PI meeting revealed current challenges and problems that could limit the availability of research infrastructures to support community needs. Multiple infrastructure operators noted that there are very few options to obtain sustainable, long-term funding for infrastructures. Infrastructures requiring on-going support to fund hardware needs, software development, and storage, among other resources. Most funding sources place time limits on such support, and the termination of funding generally results in an infrastructure becoming stagnant or disappearing altogether. Infrastructures in computing research are also constrained by the supply of human capital. Most are supported by graduate students at research universities, and as students graduate and take other jobs, infrastructure operators cannot easily replace the knowledge and skills lost.  In computing and information sciences in particular, research assistants (RAs) working on infrastructures gain valuable expertise that is very useful to the private sector, so that these RAs are susceptible to recruitment efforts from firms that again result in the loss of their skills and knowledge. 

The CISE Directorate faces a potential long-term vulnerability in its reliance on academic institutions to support and operate research infrastructures. Computing faculty are not provided any incentives to work on long-term infrastructures, as they are pushed to publish research articles focused on emerging technologies. Those who have ambitions to advance in their careers are more likely to give up on efforts to build and maintain infrastructures and move into pure research. At the leadership level, the network of infrastructure owners will face constant turnover and a dearth of "champions" who have the influence to garner and expand resources needed to keep infrastructures current and robust. The NSF could look to other disciplines for models, such as the funding of "core facilities" in biomedical research offered by the National Institutes of Health, to design new approaches to supporting the computing community's research infrastructures.

The issue of research infrastructure is a challenge for society as a whole, as these resources enable the development and improvements of a wide range of technologies that can improve applications with economic and social benefit. This can help arguments to bring infrastructure needs into the discussion about the future of computing and information science and its connection to improving the human condition.
